The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x) = (x - h)^2+k$. - Write down the values of $h$ and $k$. [2] The function $f$ can also be written in the form $f(x) = (x + p)(x - q)$, where $p,q \in \mathbb{Z^+}$. - Write down the values of $p$ and $q$. [2] - Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $f$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{h = 2}$  and

- Evaluating $f(x) = (x+1)(x-5)$ for $x = 0$, we have

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Let $f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 8$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Write down the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$. [1] - Solve the equation $f(x) = 0$. [3] - Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 0^2 - 2(0) - 8 \\[6pt]
  &= -8\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,-8)}$
is the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 8 &= 0 \hspace{4.8em} \\[6pt]
  (x + 2)(x - 4) &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.8em} \answer{x = -2,\hspace{0.25em} 4}
  $$

- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.7em} f(x) &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[6pt]
  &= \big[(x - 1)^2 - 1\big] - 8 \\[6pt]
  &= (x - 1)^2 - 9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the axis of symmetry of the
graph of $y = f(x)$ is
$\answer{x = 1}$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Let $f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 1)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. For the graph of $f$, find: - the $y$-intercept; [2] - the $x$-intercepts; [2] - the coordinates of the vertex. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 1)$ for $x = 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} f(0) &= (0 - 3)(0 + 1) \\[6pt] 
  &= (-3)(1) \\[6pt]
  &= -3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(0,-3)}$
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (x - 3)(x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{1.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
$x$-intercepts are
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(-1,0)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{C}(3,0)}$
- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.8em} f(x) &= (x - 3)(x + 1) \\[6pt]
  &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[6pt]
  &= \big[(x-1)^2 - 1\big] - 3 \\[6pt]
  &= (x-1)^2 - 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex
are  $\answer{(1,-4)}$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The equation $x^2 - kx + 1 = 0$ has two distinct real roots.
Find the possible values of $k$.
list.markScheme:
Since the quadratic function $q(x) = x^2 - kx + 1$ has two distinct real
roots, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.9em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &> 0 \\[6pt]
(-k)^2 - 4(1)(1) &> 0 \hspace{3em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac]  \\[6pt]
k^2 - 4 &> 0 \\[6pt]
k^2 &> 4 \\[7pt]
|k| &> 2 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the inequality $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} k < \hspace{-0.1em}-2 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k > 2  \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the set of possible values of $k$ is
$\answer{(-\infty,-2)\cup(2,\infty)}$

list.content: - Express $2x^2 - 8x + 9$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where $a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2] - Given that $f(x) = x - 2$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + 9$, find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x^2 - 8x + 9 &= 2\big[x^2 - 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[(x-2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  &= 2(x-2)^2 - 8 + 9 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2(x-2)^2 + 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.3em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 2x^2 - 8x + 9 \\[6pt]
  g(f(x)) &=  2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  g(x-2) &= 2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x - 2$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g(x) = 2x^2 + 1} \hspace{3.4em}
  $$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The equation $x^2 + (k-3)x - 3k = 0$ has two distinct real solutions.
Find the possible values of $k$.
list.markScheme:
Since the quadratic function $q(x) = x^2 + (k-3)x - 3k$ has two distinct
real roots, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.9em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &> 0 \\[6pt]
(k-3)^2 - 4(1)(-3k) &> 0 \hspace{3em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac]  \\[6pt]
(k^2 - 6k + 9) + 12k &> 0 \\[6pt]
k^2 + 6k + 9 &> 0 \\[6pt]
(k + 3)^2 &> 0 \\[7pt]
|k + 3| &> 0 \hspace{3em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the inequality $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3.7em} k + 3 < 0 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k + 3 > 0 \\[6pt]
k < \hspace{-0.1em} -3 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k > -3   \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the set of possible values of $k$ is
$\answer{k\in\mathbb{R}\,;\,k\neq-3}$

list.content: Consider $f(x) = x^2 + bx + c$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$. The graph of $f$ has a local minimum when $x = 2.5$. The distance between the two $x$-intercepts of the graph of $f$ is $7$. - Find the coordinates of the two $x$-intercepts. [2] - Find the value of $b$ and the value of $c$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- The axis of symmetry of the graph of $f$ is $x = 2.5$.
Hence the coordinates of the two $x$-intercepts are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \bigg(2.5-\frac{7}{2},0\bigg) = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{(-1,0)}\hspace{0.525em} \hspace{1em}\text{and}\hspace{1em}
  \bigg(2.5+\frac{7}{2},0\bigg) = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{(6,0)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The roots of the quadratic function $f(x) = x^2 + bx + c$ are
$x = -1$ and $x = 6$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.4em} f(x) &= (x + 1)(x - 6) \\[6pt]
  &= x^2 - 5x - 6\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{b = -5}$
and  $\answer{c = -6}$

list.content: - Express $3x^2 + 18x + 20$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where $a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2] - Given that $f(x) = x + 3$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 3x^2 + 18x + 20$, find $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3x^2 + 18x + 20 &= 3\big[x^2 + 6x\big] + 20 \\[6pt]
  &= 3\big[(x+3)^2 - 9\big] + 20 \\[6pt]
  &= 3(x+3)^2 - 27 + 20 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3(x+3)^2 - 7}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 3x^2 + 18x + 20 \\[6pt]
  g(f(x)) &= 3(x+3)^2 - 7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  g(x+3) &= 3(x+3)^2 - 7 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x + 3$}] \\

list.title: Question 19
list.content: A cannonball is fired from the top of a tower. The rate of change of the height, $h$, of the cannonball above the ground is modelled by $$ \begin{aligned} h'(t) = -4t + 20, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,\end{aligned} $$ where $h$ is in metres and $t$ is the time, in seconds, since the moment the cannonball was fired. - Determine the time $t$ at which the cannonball reached its maximum height. [2] After one second, the cannonball is 26 metres above the ground. - - Find an expression for $h(t)$, the height of the cannonball above the ground at time $t$. - Hence, determine the maximum height reached by the cannonball. [5] - Write down the height of the tower. [1] - Calculate the height of the cannonball $4$ seconds after it was fired. [2] The cannonball hits its target on the ground $n$ seconds after it was fired. - Find the value of $n$. [2] - Determine the total time the cannonball was above the height of the tower.[3] A second cannonball is fired from exactly halfway up the tower, with the same projectile motion as the first cannonball. - Given that both cannonballs land at the same time, determine the length of time between the first cannonball and the second cannonball being fired. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The time at which the cannonball reaches maximum height is found by solving $h'(t)=0$. We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h'(t) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  -4t + 20 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-0.275em}\tcbhighmath{t = 5 \text{ s}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - Given that $h(t)=\int h'(t)\,\mathrm{d}t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(t) &= \int{-4t+20}\,\mathrm{d}t \\[6pt]
    &= -2t^2 +20t + C
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Given that $h=26$ when $t=1$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(1) &= -2(1)^2 +20(1) + C \\[6pt]
    26 &= -2 + 20 + C \\[6pt]
    C &= 8
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore $\hspace{0.575em}\tcbhighmath{h(t) = -2t^2 +20t + 8}$.
  - We must calculate $h(5)$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(5) &= -2(5)^2 +20(5) + 8 \\[6pt]
    &= 58
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The maximum height reached is $\hspace{0.575em}\tcbhighmath{58 \text{ metres}}$.

- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \hspace{3.7em} h(0) &= -2(0)^2+20(0)+8 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{= 8 \text{ m}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 4$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \hspace{3.7em} h(5) &= -2(4)^2+20(4)+8 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{= 56 \text{ m}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Solving the equation $h(n) = 0$ for $n > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  -2n^2+20n+8 &= 0 \hspace{9em} \\[6pt] 
  &\hspace{-0.8em}\tcbhighmath{n \approx 10.4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Solving the equation $h(t) = 8$ for $t > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  -2t^2+20t+8 &= 8 \hspace{8.6em} \\[6pt]
  -2t^2+20t &= 0 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-0.8em} \tcbhighmath{t = 10 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Given that the second cannonball follows the same projectile motion as the first cannonball, the equation is the same as $h(t)$, but with a vertical translation of 4 units down (the second cannonball is launched from a height of 4 metres instead of 8 metres). We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_2(t) &= -2t^2 +20t + 4 
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Where $h_2(t)$ is the height of the second cannonball above the ground, in metres, at time $t$ seconds.
  Solving the equation $h_2(t) = 0$ for $t > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  -2t^2+20t+4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 10.20 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The second cannonball will take $10.2$ seconds to land, whereas the first cannonball will take $10.4$ seconds.
  Therefore, the second cannonball was fired $\hspace{0.25em}\tcbhighmath{0.2 \text{ seconds later}}$.

list.title: Question 22
list.content: Find the range of possible values for $p$ such that $e^{2x}+2\ln p = 4e^x$ has at least one real solution.
list.markScheme:
The equation is a hidden quadratic. Let $k=e^x$

$$
\begin{align*}
k^2 - 4k + 2 \ln p &= 0  \tag*{\textbf{R1}}
\end{align*} 
$$

Using the discriminant we can say a quadratic equation has at least one real solution if $ b^2-4ac\geq 0$.
Therefore, we have at least one real solution for $k$ if

$$
\begin{align*}
(-4)^2-4(2\ln p) &\geq 0 \tag*{\textbf{M1A1}}\\[7pt]
16-8\ln p &\geq 0 \\[7pt]
8\ln p &\leq 16  \\[7pt]
\ln p &\leq 2 \\[6pt]
&\hspace{-2.33em}\tcbhighmath{0 < p \leq e^2} \hspace{3em} \text{($\ln p > 0$)} \tag*{\textbf{A1A1}}\\[-11pt]
\end{align*} 
$$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
The line $y = x + 1$ touches the graph of the function
$g(x) = 2x^2 + kx + 3$ at one point. Find the possible values of $k$.
list.markScheme:
Letting $g(x) = y$ we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
2x^2 + kx + 3 &= x + 1   \\[10pt]
2x^2 + (k-1)x + 2 &= 0 \\[10pt]
[\hspace{0.1em}\text{discriminant of quadratic above}\hspace{0.1em}] &= 0 \\[10pt]
(k-1)^2 - 4(2)(2) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac] \\[10pt]
k^2 - 2k + 1 - 16 &= 0 \\[10pt]
k^2 - 2k - 15 &= 0 \\[10pt]
(k - 5)(k + 3) &= 0 \\[10pt]
&\hspace{-0.5em} \answer{k = -3, \, 5}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^2 + kx$ and $g(x) = x + k$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where
$k$ is a constant.
The graphs of $y = f(x)$ and $y = g(x)$ intersect at two distinct
points.
Find the possible values of $k$.
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation $f(x) = g(x)$ in the form
$ax^2 + bx + c = 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^2 + kx &= x + k \\[6pt]
x^2 + (k-1)x - k &= 0 \hspace{3.1em}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the quadratic
function $q(x) = x^2 + (k-1)x - k$ has two distinct real roots.
Therefore we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.9em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &> 0 \\[6pt]
(k-1)^2 - 4(1)(-k) &> 0 \hspace{3em}  [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac]  \\[6pt]
(k^2 - 2k + 1) + 4k &> 0 \\[6pt]
k^2  + 2k + 1 &> 0 \\[6pt]
(k + 1)^2 &> 0 \\[7pt]
|k+1| &> 0 \hspace{3em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the inequality $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3.7em} k + 1 < 0 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k + 1 > 0 \\[6pt]
k < \hspace{-0.1em} -1 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k > -1   \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the set of possible values of $k$ is
$\answer{\mathbb{R}\setminus\{-1\}}$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Let $f(x) = p - \dfrac{16}{x}$, for $x \neq 0$, where $p$ is a constant.
The line $y = x - p$ intersects the graph of $y = f(x)$ at two distinct
points.
Find the possible values of $p$.
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation $f(x) = x - p$ in the form
$ax^2 + bx + c = 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
p - \dfrac{16}{x} &= x - p \\[6pt]
2p - \dfrac{16}{x} &= x \\[11pt]
2px - 16 &= x^2 \\[14pt]
\hspace{0.2em} x^2 - 2px + 16 &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the quadratic
function $q(x) = x^2 - 2px + 16$ has two distinct real roots.
Therefore we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.8em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &> 0 \\[6pt]
(-2p)^2 - 4(1)(16) &> 0 \hspace{3em}  [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac]  \\[6pt]
4p^2 - 64 &> 0 \\[6pt]
p^2 - 16 &> 0 \\[6pt]
p^2 &> 16 \\[7pt]
|p| &> 4 \hspace{3em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the inequality $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} p < \hspace{-0.1em}-4 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} p > 4  \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the set of possible values of $p$ is
$\answer{(-\infty,-4)\cup(4,\infty)}$
